Endless Sky is a great game. It might not seem like much of one at first glance, but it really pulls you in once you start playing. It's a lot of fun running missions and generally trying to figure out how to make more money and do more things. I especially liked the non-intrusive and responsive tutorial at the start - the game as a whole really shines through its writing. I'm still enjoying running deliveries across the galaxy, so I can't vouch for the entire storyline, but the fact that there even is one that blends into the world so well is very impressive.  I feel that the controls and mechanics could be more friendly - arrow keys were a surprise, as was the fact that ships in the 31st century don't have retrograde thrusters, and that you have to turn 180 degrees and thrust to stop. It's also a little jarring that you can simply jump into a sector to be absolutely demolished by a pirate cruiser, though loading from the previous save makes it no big deal.  All in all, this is a great game and I recommend it whole-heartedly, especially since it's free AND open source. The developer did a great job on this.

In the mid-90's there was a game called Escape Velocity released by Ambrosia Software, where you flew around in spaceships in a 2d universe, completing economic or combat based missions. I recieved a copy free copy of this game on a MacWorld Magazine disk and was immmediately hooked. I spent endless hours of my youth exploring the the Escape Velocity univerise. It's an open world, where you follow quests and decide which faction you were going to join and others that you were going to become enemies with. You could join the Confederates, Rebels, Pirates, or just remain an independent trader.   Endless Sky is clearly modelled after the Escape Velocity series (Escape Velocity, Escape Velocity Override, and Escape Velocity Nova) and anyone who was a fan of those games should be playing this.  That being said, for me personally, Endless Sky brought back a lot of nostalgia from my gaming days in the 90's. Growing up I had a Macintosh computer, which really limited my computer gaming choices. There were the early Bungie games (Pathways Into Darkness, Marathon, and Myth 2) as well as Blizzard's Warcraft and Starcraft games. Bungie, Bllizzard, and Ambrosia Software were my three go to gaming companies and they all sparked my passion for gaming.   Enough nostalgia, let's talk about the game. You start off with a trading ship and have to complete several trading missions in order to pay off the morgage you got for your first space ship. As the game goes on, you begin to explore the galaxy, earn more credits, learn more about the main plot, and eventually build and upgrade your ship. There appears to be one main storyline to this game (as opposed to the EV series where you followed a certain faction's story line) but you can go about it at your own pace. Some side missions pop up which also add an element of intrigue. All the missions require you to either take people/cargo somewhere, to fight other ships, or analzye something. At both the beginning and end of the mission there are no cutscenes but instead you read and sometimes make decisions on what was said.   The combat is a bit difficult to get used to at first and you'll need to buy another ship and upgrade a bit before taking anyone on. The first few hours playing this, not unlike my high school days, I always got my ♥♥♥ kicked. If you keep grinding out the trade missions, you'll soon have a ship to be reckoned with and can go face to face with everyone who wronged you. Also you can hire a fleet of ships to help fight along side you although you'll have to pay them x amount of credits to retain their services.   I've played this game for several hours and it has kept me entertained and curious on how the story line will unfold. It's not ground-breaking at all, sometimes I got lost trying to figure out where the story picked up at, and the game is outdated graphics-wise but I'm recommending it.   I'm also looking forward to the user created mods. Escape Velocity had a similar editor where there were a lot of great user created mods released for free and kept the game new and exciting after you exhausted the original game.   If your curious, give it a shot. You got nothing to lose but time - it's free.

I've had this game for only a few days, and I've played for almost 48 hours.   Granted, I've had it running in the background for some of that, but the point stands.   This game is great.   Pros: Still in development - you can talk with the developer and suggest improvements This also means new content is coming out regularly  Solid gameplay - this game just feels good to play. The ships range from tiny to massive, and their handling changes as well. Great selection of stuff to customize with that forces you to balance heat, power generation, and ship handling with the amount of weapons or cargo you want to carry.   Interesting world: this game has a LOT of lore to dig into if you want to find it, or you can just take it as it is. up to you.   Easily moddable: I haven't installed any yet, but mods take the form of plugins that you just place in the appropriate folder, and its designed for you to be able to change things easily.  Open source: You can help make this game.   Low system requirements: anyone with a PC can play this pretty much  Cons:   Only one minor downside Still in development: while there are benefits to a living game, one of the downsides is content with some loose ends to be filled in later. This also means there are a few minor bugs here and there. If you're reading this after 1.0.0 then this will probably be a non issue, so download this awesome free game.  Any other issues I've had are already on the list to be fixed, so don't worry about that.

What do I have to say about this game..  Endless Sky is a completely free, top-down, 2D space game. But there's more to it than that; think Elite Dangerous meets 2D with text-based story telling charm.   Gameplay:   Gameplay typically goes along the lines of this: Game: 'Buy your first ever spacecraft! Pick from a transport, cargo ship, or a fighter!' Player: 'I want the fighter!' Banks: 'Let me just set your mortgage appropriately...' *Proceeds to suffer paycheck to paycheck*  Yeah.. Never start with the fighter. Bad idea.  Once you get the basics down, a lot of the gameplay boils down to your character trying to earn a living through either pirating, transporting tourists around, and/or shipping cargo around the galaxy, and avoiding pirate raids. Be warned, this game does take a little trial and error before you're able to get the hang of it.  What catches my attention is the surprising amount of story a free game like this has. The random events can range from a funny little fetch quest (Go save my pookie!), to helping scientsts with something, to throwing you the chance to go off on a sudden story quest.  The writing has a charm to it. The dialog is surprisingly well written, every planet, starport, and space station has it's own bio and photo (There are a LOT of planets), and the science is well researched.   OVERALL: 8/10  Upsides:   This game is clearly someones passion project, and the passion shows. From how far I've played, the characters have personality, the writing is vivid, the planets are well thought out, and the story that I've experienced thus far is interesting. I can honestly say this is the first time a completely free game has thoroughly impressed me. This game has well over 15-20+ hours of potential minimum playtime.  Well thoughtout universe and story!  Huge number of ships, upgrades, and planets!  No Microtransactions!  Good autosave system!  Forgot to save and now your flagship is destroyed, along with that cargo that was going to net you 124,000 creds? Don't worry about it, you can pick up back at whatever planet you last took off from!    Downsides:   The initial tutorial quests, which do have some variation (+Brownie Point Get), don't cover as much as they could. They explain the game concepts well, but the only way to learn the controls, how to hyperjump, target, fire, et cetera, is to look in your options menu. This isn't a huge issue, as there aren't many controls for the game and they're fairly simple at that.  The UI could use a little improvement. I'd like to have my flagship's shield and hull stats next to the rest of my fleet, and the enemy's stats nearby, rather than have all three seperated. It makes it difficult to properly manage a ship (let alone a fleet) during combat.  There isn't any way that I've found that will make all of the ships in your fleet jump at once, they go at their own pace and become scattered between planets if you move too fast.    Still not convinced that this game may be a hidden gem? Try it out, it's free, you have nothing to loose!

A top-down space trading/combat game. It is a very faithful recreation of the Escape Velocity series, for any familiar with that (probably the closest I've found yet, even moreso than Naev, which was the closest before this). It has several improvements over EV. Movement is less of a hassle because you can tell your ship to maneuver on autopilot to accomplish things like docking, landing, and lining up with a target. Of course, you can also move manually to fly circles around the enemy or avoid missiles. You can take out bank loans to purchase ships you can't afford yet (in fact you start with a ship mortgage which you will need to pay off as your first hurdle in the game). You have to pay your crew salaries, but you can upgrade them with weapons to make capturing ships easier. You can also loot the ships' equipment as well as their cargohold. The map is very informative, allowing you to see what systems sell what outfits and ships, and what trade routes might be profitable (assuming you've explored the system already). I haven't gotten into any storyline missions, if there are any, but so far I've been having a blast. After trading and missioning for a while I just bought my first fancy combat ship and captured a few wingmen. There is even a ship you may find that pays homage to good old Cap'n Hector.  Pros: - Very close recreation of Escape Velocity with several improvements. - Many different ships and weapons to play around with. - Emerssive world; other ships send you chats and each planet has a story behind it. - Loans and crew salaries give a sense of realism and urgency to keep making money. - Very stable.  Cons: - Sometimes the NPC ship chatter gets repetative and relentless. - Early game can be rather boring (though that might be my fault for starting off as a trader). - Some things are never explained well. For instance, only cargo/passenger missions appear until you earn a combat rank, whereupon other mission types are generated as well. - Some of the sound effects seem rather low-quality (especially the beam lasers, they just sound like a couple keys pressed on a keyboard).  This is a fun game for anyone who enjoys open world arcade-style space sims. And if you ever loved any of the Escape Velocity games, do yourself a favor and give this a try.

If you enjoy just exploring, well, you can buy and sell resources as you make a dash across the galaxy.  All of the customization parts are faction-based, and the factions are very well spread out. In other words, to build the best ship, you are actually required to transcend the entire galaxy to collect the parts you need. Some can't even be bought. Instead, they have to be stolen off other ships, which adds even more difficulty to building 'ideal' ships.  The only thing I don't like is the heavy limitations on engine/weapon setups. Weapons, you're limited not only by what your ship can carry and how many weapon ports it has, you're also limited on how much 'weapon space' you have, if the other two werent limiting enough. Engines, same thing, minus the weapon ports. What if I wanted to create a rideable missile, or simply put stronger weapons on my ship? You are allowed to put on as much shielding as you want though, which I find odd compared to the weapons/engines. Last I knew, shields were more important than engines in heavy combat. (I did modify a ship to have a few hundred engines though, and steadily dropped to <5fps as the stars zipping by merged into a massive white background. I was going a few hundred thousand units/second on a game intended for ~900 tops, lol)  Theres just so much to do on here that it becomes difficult to get off. You think to yourself, 'one last run, then I'm going to bed'. Three hours later, you realize you're still playing. Deffinately worth its whopping cost of 'free', unless you have to work in the morning. If you do, wait until the weekend before getting this.

If you're into economy/trade simulators and space, then you'll probably enjoy Endless Sky. I gave it a try and found that it offers enough variety that you'll enjoy tinkering with it for a few hours before you really make up your mind about it. Overall, your gameplay falls into three categories:  1. Make money, or invest in ways to make you even more money 2. Keep exploring the map until you hit the edges and begin unlocking more of the plot 3. Have pew-pew battles in space that involve ships the size of postage stamps pointing lines at each other  Until you have a decent amount of money saved up, you'll want to skip #3. In fact, you have so few jumps worth of fuel that you can't explore #2 without risking ending up in a system without a shipyard or with the shipyard on a planet where the authorities won't let you land. You're left to beg for one more jump worth of fuel from another ship in the system, and you'll get to watch the ship VERY SLOWLY putter over to your position before coughing up some fuel.  So, that leaves us with #1: making money. You're already starting in the hole with a 0.4% daily interest mortgage for your ship, so you can't spend any time exploring. You have to head straight to the grind. By the time you've paid off ship #1 and have moved onto ship #2, you'll have the basic mechanics down. Find a mission or missions in the area you want to go. Figure out which systems you're stopping in to refuel along the way. Use the market data comparison to buy the most profitable cargo possible to sell in that system. Sell the cargo, pick up new missions as applicable, and wash, rinse, repeat.   A lot. For hours.  With a few million in the bank, you can stretch your legs a bit more and explore around the edges of the map. You can even start investing in multiple ships and building up your own combat or trade armada. But, expect to watch your ship whoosh to new systems, slowly rotate, and then whoosh on the next system over and over. And over.  For a free-to-play title, you should give this a shot. It is well put together, visually pleasing (with lots of CC licensed astronomy artwork), and has a decent storyline. The audio is lacking a bit, with the sounds largely coming from the pew-pew of lasers and the whoosh of jumping from system to system.

Let me just start by saying that this is the best zero dollars I have ever spent on a game. I am not sure where to start, so let me tell you the story of Captain Vic Edwards, Pirate Hunter, in my own words.  Young Mr. Edwards walked into the bank, he was sure of this. He knew what he wanted more than anything was to pilot his own ship. Even if it meant going into immense debt in order to buy it. After handling his business with the bank, he jetted straight for the shipyard. Three models are manufactured at Edwards' home planet, New Boston. The first, a Shuttle, well balanced for any small jobs a new captain may take on. The second, a clunky Star Barge, made for shipping and not much else. The last one stopped him dead in his tracks. It was beautiful. The Sparrow, the cheapest interstellar ship rated for combat. The salesman warns you as you prepare to take off that a very high percentage of new pilots die within one week of purchasing a Sparrow. Well, it was too late for that, He christened the ship 'short sword' and left the planet. Space was everything Edwards had dreamed of. After a few random courrier missions to some close star systems, he decided to explore. At the rate he was going, it would take forever to pay off the loan. There must be faster money out there, he thought. Then, in an uninhabited system, he saw them. Pirates were attacking a Star Barge. His first instinct was to flee, jump to another system, to safety. He couldn't let that happen, though. He had to intervene. He was apprehensive about opening fire so close to the friendly ship, especially since he hadn't fired one shot since buying his ship. It was now or never, he pulled the trigger. Shots went everywhere. His ship pointed in all directions, Edwards attempting to aim at the pirate while avoiding the friendly. Every beam of energy seemed to pass over or under the friendly, and the few that made it, actually hit the pirate. Then the pirate switched targets to Edwards. The Star Barge, free of bombardment jumped out of the system. It was Edwards vs. the pirate. Equally matched in terms of equipment, the two ships squared off, kind of. Edwards aim was so bad, when his shield was almost depleted, he tried to jump systems. no luck, the energy blaster fire was enough force to push his ship so that the hyperdrive wouldn't kick in. Shield was completely depleted and Edwards was trying to outmaneuver the insatiable pirate. Finally, help arrives, in the form of a massive Republic Defense Fleet. One Corvette annihalates the pirate in a few shots while a pair of capital ships roll up. The sight of saviors is short lived as an opposing fleet of pirates jumps in from the opposing system. Edwards jumped back to safety and landed on the nearest planet. After landing at the spaceport, Edwards looked up at the heavily damaged hull and said, 'I need a bigger ship' After several different ships, loads of cargo, a mad scientist, a woman who spends way too much money on a dog, a few escort missions, a ton of pirate bounties and meeting a couple of alien races, Captain Vic Edwards is a known name in the Galaxy. His fleet is headed by a Bactrian city ship known as 'The Citadel' he is acompanied by 2 Heavy Interceptors and an alien heavy warship with an extreme shield. All are armed with a combination of human and alien weapons and equipment. With over 200 million credits in the bank, life is good for Captain Edwards.  TLDR: Download this game. It is awesome.
